metadata.case_name: Nar Singh and Roshan Singh v. State

facts.text: Twenty-four persons, among them the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.
Sixteen were acquitted and the remaining eight were convicted.
On appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, five more were acquitted and the convictions were upheld only for the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, and one Nanhu Singh.
High Court misread evidence and mixed up Nanhu Singh with Bechan Singh, convicting Nanhu instead of Bechan.
High Court Judges realised mistake, communicated with State Government, which remitted sentence on Nanhu Singh and directed his release.
Application under Article 134(1)(c) by Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh for certificate.
High Court granted certificate to Nanhu Singh due to stigma of conviction despite remission; wrongly granted to Nar Singh and Roshan Singh thinking bound by 'case' as whole appeal.
Nanhu Singh did not appeal to Supreme Court; only Nar Singh and Roshan Singh appealed.
High Court finding: more than five persons involved; eye-witnesses identified the two appellants.
Attack by a number of persons at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.

legal_issues.text: Whether the certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was properly granted to Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, given High Court's view that 'case' means the appeal as a whole.
Whether, upon grant of certificate under Article 134(1)(c), Supreme Court becomes an ordinary Court of appeal bound to hear on facts and law.
Whether convictions under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149 IPC are sustainable, given evidence of more than five attackers and identification.

petitioner_arguments.text: Having obtained a certificate under Article 134(1)(c), Supreme Court has become an ordinary Court of appeal and is bound to hear their case as an appellate Court both on facts and on law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Reliance on Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra; Article 134(1)(c)

court_reasoning.text: 'Case' in Article 134(1)(c) means the case of each individual person, not the appeal as a whole; High Court wrongly thought bound to grant certificate to all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court misdirected itself and did not exercise judicial discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court can determine if certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was rightly granted; discretion must be judicially exercised; here it was fettered by misinterpretation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Treat appellants' case as one under Article 136 for special leave.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence against appellants is clear; High Court believed eye-witnesses identifying them; more than five persons involved justifies Section 149 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to interfere with convictions or sentences.

holdings.text: Certificate under Article 134(1)(c) wrongly granted to appellants as High Court misdirected itself on meaning of 'case'.
Supreme Court not bound as ordinary appellate court upon certificate; can review its propriety and treat as Article 136 petition.
Convictions under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149 IPC proper; no interference with findings or sentences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra
precedents_cited.relevance: Deals with section 205 Government of India Act, 1935; not applicable to Article 134(1)(c)
Certificate must show discretion invoked and exercised

precedents_cited.case_name: Radha Krishn Das v. Rai Krishn Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate must show discretion invoked and exercised
No interference with discretion unless strong grounds
No interference with discretion unless strong grounds

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Indar Singh v. Kanshi Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Superior court must remit or exercise discretion if lower court misdirected

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences for which appellants tried and convicted; Section 149 justified due to more than five persons

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court; discretion judicial; reviewable

outcome.summary: Certificates under Article 134(1)(c) wrongly granted to appellants; appeal treated as special leave petition under Article 136 and dismissed; convictions and sentences upheld.

key_quotes.text: 'Case' as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation rejecting High Court's view on Article 134(1)(c)

key_quotes.text: Ordinarily no certificate can be granted to them as there is nothing of an exceptional nature in their cases.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's own admission of no merit in appellants' cases

key_quotes.text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved.
key_quotes.speaker: court
